question.body: Generally, monosaccharides that are not processed in the digestive system can cause what dietary condition?

response.feedback: Correct. Sugars in the large intestine increase water content of the stool, causing diarrhea.
Incorrect. Sugars in the large intestine increase water content of the stool causing diarrhea. Decrease in water content causes constipation.
Incorrect. There are numerous digestive issues that alter the color of stool, but sugar content is not one.
Incorrect. Humans do not produce polysaccharides from monosaccharides in the digestive system.

question.body: Why canâ€™t there be a single brush-border enzyme to break down the three common disaccharides?

multiple_choice.choice: Bacterial enzymes are required to break down lactose.
a-dextrins are too small to be broken down by these enzymes.
There is only one enzyme to break down disaccharides, the other brush-border enzymes break down starch.

response.feedback: Incorrect. If the brush-border enzyme for lactose is missing, bacteria will break down these molecules for energy and cause conditions such as diarrhea.
Correct. Each enzyme can only catalyze a specific reaction, so each disaccharide would need a different enzyme.
Incorrect. A-dextrin is actually a short chain of glucose that is converted to glucose by a brush-border enzyme.
Incorrect. Starch is broken down by amylase which is not a brush-border enzyme.
